text: I'm going to carry on now with our next presentation for this budget workshop. And now we will shift to gears to hear from the Mayor's office. And at this time, I would like to welcome our Chief of staff for the Mayor's office, ms. Marvelette Hunter and Valerie Barry, to provide the Mayor's Office department budget presentation. I want to thank you all for your presentation station and turn the floor to you. Excellent. Good morning, chair and council members and council representatives. I am here today with our CFO, Valerie Berry, and Valerie has ridden side chair with me for the last six budget presentations, so really glad that she is here. We also have several members of the Mayor's office executive team who are present, and I would like for them to please stand and be recognized right now. Thank you all. I may have a couple of them come forward during our Q and A time period. If you have any additional questions that relate to their specific areas of expertise. After I finish the budget this year, I'm excited to be able to be here with you in person instead of virtually, which was our last fate. We have certainly had our fair share of challenges through this administration, but just like Houston, we've proven that we are resilient and that we can come through anything, even a global pandemic. I'd like to publicly thank the city of Houston for their support of Mayor Turner and this administration. And I also want to thank the 22,000 employees who work tirelessly to serve the citizens of Houston. Today. I'm pleased to present to you the FY 23 Mayor's Office proposed budget. And if we could have our first slide, please. Here is the Functional organization chart summarizing our six General fund divisions. First, we have our executive offices, which includes our boards and commissions, education, constituent services, community relations and our council relations. Next we have our Agenda office, the Economic Development Office, government relations, Communications and our Veteran Affairs Office. You'll note here the total budget for each of the six divisions as well as the number of FTEs for each of those respective divisions. Next slide, please. There are two special revenue funds administered by the Mayor's office. First, we have our Cable TV Special Fund, whose functional organization chart you see before you with the budget and the number of FTEs that are represented. Next slide, please. You'll see here the other special fund, which is our Tourism and Promotion Special Fund. And this organizational chart shows the budget and the FTEs for each of those respective divisions. The tourism and promotion fund includes our special events, trade and international affairs, and it also includes cultural affairs. Next slide, please. The next four slides are going to share with you our course services within the Mayor's office. First we looked at divisions that are mandated by federal or state statutes or municipal code. And then we looked at divisions that were created to meet the needs of the citizens of Houston. Now, although most of our divisions are not statutorily required, the citizens of Houston certainly depend on those services that we provide on a daily basis. So on this particular slide, you see our Office of Education, our Boards and commissions and our Constituent Services divisions. And I just wanted to note just a couple of highlights from each one of those and the rest is there for your reading but heart Houston youth. That is one of the Mayor's signature initiatives and that is administered through our Education Office. And we are on track currently this year to provide 12,000 jobs for our youth ages 16 to 24. And I will make note that when that program first started, we were only providing 450 jobs. And now we have brought on the private sector and all of the additional jobs now are private sector related. I'll also note that as far as our Boards and Commissions is concerned, we have, and many people don't know this, over 160 Boards and Commissions, and that's a lot of people that we have to administrate over. And then lastly, for Constituent Services, just making a note that there are approximately 1400 pieces of correspondence that comes in to the Mayor's office on a monthly basis. And with a very lean staff of two, we're able to move that and be responsive to the citizens of Houston. Next slide, please. Here we have our agenda office, the Economic Development office and the Special Events office. And all of these are statutorily mandated. I wanted to highlight a couple of things, and that is through our Economic Development Office. This is our office that administers the tours, the management districts, the tax abatements, and is responsible for over $25 million in billings through the Industrial Assessments each year. And then I wanted to also make note of our Special Events Office. Now that we are past COVID or post COVID and beginning to return to our mini events, this particular office produces about 2000 special events per year for the City of Houston. Next slide, please. Here we have our Intergovernmental Relations Office, our Cultural Affairs, as well as our Veteran Affairs. And I wanted to highlight that our Gr team was mainly responsible for helping to bring $630,000,000 of ARPA funds, which is really being relied upon to help us get through not only this year, but the next two years of deficits that we were experiencing due to COVID. So very important, their work that they're doing. And then our Veteran Affairs. I wanted to point out that Houston hosts the second largest veteran population in the country, over 300,000 veterans, and this office basically provides services, referral services to that population. Next slide, please. Lastly, we have our communications office and our trade and international affairs and also Houston Television. And I wanted to point out that, of course, communications statutorily required by the Texas Public Information Act. But I wanted to point out that we receive about 170 TPS per year and over 270 requests for proclamations or letters from the Mayor's office. And so that is a very busy office with a staff of two in trade and international affairs. This office is critical in coordinating the Mayor's abroad trade missions and also in marketing the City of Houston as an international city which we're very proud of. And then, lastly, Houston television. And that is mandated by Chapter 37 of the City of Houston Code of Ordinances. And of course the impact is better transparency of government and making sure that we have an informed public. Next slide please. This slide summarizes our revenues for the three funds that are managed in the Mayor's office. We have our general fund and we also have Houston television special revenue fund and the tourism and promotion special revenue fund. From our FY 22 estimate, the General Fund has increased in revenues of approximately $887,000 for FY 23 and this is primarily due to the projected revenue from the new Digital Kiosk, which will begin generating revenue in the fourth quarter of 22. The revenue projected for FY 23 is for a full year of those revenues and the revenue projection for FY 22 was only prorated for a May start date. So there's also a $33,000 increase in the Industrial District assessment revenue due to the expected increase in taxable values by 6.3 million. For our Houston Television Fund, we are projecting an overall revenue decrease of 69,000 over the FY 22 estimate and this is primarily due to the projected decrease of the Peg fees, the public education and governmental revenues. And this is something that I've been sharing with Council for the last few years. That trend is continuing. Finally, for our Tourism and Promotion Fund, we are estimating an approximate $2.95 million increase in revenue from our FY 22 estimates and the increase is primarily due to the projected post pandemic increase in hotel Occupancy tax revenues, which we're very excited about based on information that has been provided by Houston. First, as you will recall, the FY 21 revenues took a substantial hit as a result of COVID nineteen's impact and so we are now projecting for FY 22 having a gradual comeback and for FY 23 revenue budget reflects a very strong return to pre COVID activity. Next slide please. This slide reiterates the largest drivers of the revenue increases and decreases for FY 23 and most of which I discussed on the previous slide. General Fund revenue from the Digital Kiosk contract, HTV, the Peg, contributions from state franchise fees and a chargeback to funds for HTV. And lastly, tourism promotion. The hot receipts come back to pre COVID levels. Next slide please. This slide captures the expenditure comparison for all of our funds between the year in FY 22 estimate and the FY 23 proposed budget. So the General Fund shows an expenditure increase of $230,000 or 2.9%. However, this percentage includes the net adjustments which I'll talk about a little bit later for contractual municipal hope, pay increases, health insurance and restricted accounts. The almost $2.1 million increase in Houston Television Special Revenue Fund is primarily due to the projection in capital projects from year to year. So the FY 23 planned capital project improvements include the upgrade for the City Hall chambers, video control room, which was much needed, the new build of the City Council chambers and the terminal room along with the few much smaller projects. So these funds are capital dollars that are restricted for capital use only, so they cannot be used for administrative purposes. In the Tourism Special Revenue Fund, we project an increase of $3.1 million in expenditures or 17.47% from the FY 22 budget. And this is primarily due to the increase in the city's net receipts of the hot taxes and thus the city's payment going out to the arts partner houston Arts Alliance is projected to increase. As noted earlier, our FY 23 budget reflects a strong return to precovid activity and therefore, again an increase in the payment to the arts partner is anticipated. Next slide please. The next three slides provides a graphic representation of our personnel versus non personnel budgeted expenses for the Mayor's office's three funds. So to elaborate on that, the Mayor's Office General fund is 65% personnel expenditures. Of the remaining 35%, 68% of that is for the general fund transfer to subsidize special events. So the restricted accounts comprise 22% of this portion, leaving only 10% of the non personnel budget for services and supplies and those things like the novice account, office expenses, travel, parking and the like. Next slide, please. The Houston Television Special Revenue Fund is 26% personnel expenditures. Of the remaining 74%, more than half is for the planned capital improvement and more than a third is for the contractual payment to Houston Media Source. And this is the city's public access channel partner. The services and supplies account for only 6% and the restricted accounts also take another 6% of this portion. Next slide, please. Lastly, the tourism promotion special revenue fund is 15% personnel expenditures and 85% other. And please keep in mind that this is the fund where we receive our hot taxes. So therefore the personnel budget is relatively very small. 92% of the other charges are to pay the arts partner for the hot agreement and then supplies and services are there for only about 7% of the other for the entire fund. Next slide please. This slide gives a great summary of the net change in expenditure budget from FY 22 to FY 23. The slide illustrates the net increase of $230,000 from the FY 22 budget to FY 23 proposed budget. And this represents a 2.9% change as discussed on slide number eleven. So beginning at the very top of this chart, you'll see that the Mayor's office FY 22 operating budget is $6.95 million. So once we add to that our restricted account budget of 621,000 FY 22 contractual municipal hope increases of 3% of 140,000 revised projection of restricted accounts of 76,000 the FY 22 council surplus of 10,000, which was granted to us from council member Cisanero's Office for an Intern, and the Mayor's Office of Education and Funding for marketing specialists and special events and program adjustments that we took in the Economic Development Office for a total FY 22 budget of $7.9 million. Now, the next two areas, shaded areas on the chart, the blocks include our proposed operating budget adjustments for FY 23, and the first item is the reverse of the one time funding from Council Member Cisnero's office, the FY 22 surplus, FY 21 surplus, and the balance of the annualized funding amount for the economic development programming. So, added to this are the contractual adjustments for hope increases, health and benefits offset by a reduction in the restricted accounts taking. All of the increases and the decreases from the FY 22 operating budget yields the proposed FY 23 budget of $8.16 million for the Mayor's office. Next slide, please. This slide provides a brief narrative of each fund's expenditure highlights for your reference, and we discuss the expenditure highlights that are listed on slide number eleven. The general fund expense budget includes funding for contractual municipal hope pay increases, health benefits and restricted accounts. And some of the highlights of the fund include funding for capital improvements through Houston Television and in the Tourism Promotion Special Revenue Fund, the increase being attributed to the increase in hotel occupancy tax. Next slide, please. This concludes the financial portion of the Mayor's Office FY 23 budget presentation. For your reference, we have included our office demographics and some just some of our FY 22 accomplishments in the appendix section. Thank you, and I'll be happy to answer any questions that you may have. And we also have our executive staff here in chambers to assist with questions that you may have regarding their specific areas of focus. I know that we have Andy Icken here from economic development. Why don't you all stand up everybody. So thank you all so much again. So we do have Ted Irving who is here, we have representatives from Veteran Affairs and we have representatives from Special Events as well as our Executive Offices. So turn it over to you. Any questions that you may have, we're happy to answer. Thank you very much, Ms. Hunter. And your staff is well represented. Great to see everyone here in the chamber with you. We also have been joined by a few colleagues and staff members. Council member Sally Alcorn has joined us and has been here this morning along with staff from council member Tasha Jackson as well as council member Michael Kubosh's office. So I wanted to acknowledge everyone here, we do have a couple of our council members in the queue before we get to our public speakers, but first, let's hear from Council Member Alcorn. Thank you, Chair, and thank you ms. Hunter, the big increases were in the HTV and then to the arts. I think I submitted those in writing, but you've covered them here. So I appreciate that. If we could have you or Mr. Irving elaborate a little bit more on the capital improvements that are being made. This include what's already been done in the chamber? Is more stuff coming? What's going on in the control room? A little bit more color around what I will allow serving to provide a little bit more detail regarding some of the improvements. But as you recall, we did a lot of improvements here. The lighting, of course, the sound. We still have some additional work to do. And those funds that we have that are part of the budget are specifically for capital improvements only. So you will see some additional work, but I'll allow him to elaborate further. Good morning. Good morning. To answer your question on the capital improvements, the city council horseshoe area was a phase one. And so the phase two is the control room that is behind this space. And at one point in time, that control room as well as the annex chambers control room had not been updated. There have been no updates excuse me, since 1997. They are extremely outdated. But due to the Cares Act, the annex control room has been modernized with virtual technology. In the next phase, the new build that Chief Hunter is discussing that we are working to have started here, hopefully in July, FY 23, will be this control room to have it modernized. Thank you, Council Member and Mr. Irving, I know having worked with you recently on the technology, the TTI committee, we are still tweaking some things. So, council Member, it is very much an ongoing program with coordination with the speakers and the It platforms and HTV, of course, trying to coordinate it all. So we thank you for that ongoing effort. Next we'll hear from Council member Cayman staff. Thank you, chair. Thank you, Ms. Hunter. Ms. Hunter, I was curious if you could speak to, given the city's budgetary constraints, any unmet needs or really particularly critical unmet needs that you all have identified. Well, I don't think we have any critical unmet needs at current. I think the biggest challenge that we face is that over the last several years, we have trimmed our budgets and kept everything very, very tight. And so in some instances, we've actually had to eliminate vacancies. And therefore our staffing is at a minimal right now. So as we continue to respond to citizens calls and all of the other things that we have to do within the office, it does present a challenge. But as far as unmet met needs, I don't think that we have any major ones at this point. Thank you for that question. We have a follow up question now in the queue from Council Member Alcorn. Thank you, Chair. On the Kiosk revenue, how many kiosks does that represent? Trying to remember. I think we have a contract for 25, but I'm going to have Andy Icken to come forward and answer those specific questions. Thank you. Good morning, Mr. Ickin. Welcome to the chamber. Good morning. Chief of staff is correct. The first segment, if you remember, council passed the first 25. We're well on the way to do that right now. They have been very well received and the advertising revenue was exceeding the expectations that we had at that time. I just saw one going in this morning as I was coming in on Prairie and Fanon. So that'll be 25 within 75. 75 within fiscal year 23. Yeah, we're doing about five a month right now. That's the pace at which they are letting contracts and doing everything right now. I wouldn't be surprised if they don't come back to us very soon. If remember, we put a pause at 25. All the feedback we're getting, I'm not sure if council has any direct feedback has been very positive. Thank you. It might be helpful, director and chief, to see a map of all of that. I know at some point to get that update would be very we have such a map and we'll get that for you. Excellent. Very good. Well, I believe that is it for comments from the Horseshoe. Both council and staff have had their opportunity to speak. So we'll turn to those in public comment with the five virtual speakers that have signed up. We're seeing two of whom are here online or perhaps three. And we're going to start with Ms. Saba Blanding. Ms. Blanding, we may 1 hear from you. Good morning. Thank you for your time. I had a couple of questions. The first was that on slide two it says the executive office develops and coordinates all city policies. Can we return to a budget hearings where the public can ask department directors their questions directly? If not, why not? And then my second question is on slide 28. You mentioned initiatives with Houston's unhoused community. What efforts are being made to be proactive and mitigate evictions? Our housing department is grossly underfunded with a budget of only $400,000. Houston renters, I mean, to quote the Houston Chronicle, houston renters are now more cost burdened and evicted at a higher rate than renters in Dallas, Chicago or Atlanta. In 2019, one in eleven renter households in Harris County had an eviction notice posted on their door. I know Harris and Houston are different, but we have a lot of overlap. And an analysis by the eviction lab at Princeton University found 16 Houston apartment complexes have filed for more than 100 evictions each and over the course of the pandemic. So the first question is about thank you, Ms. Landing, Ms. Blanding, thank you for your question. Your time has expired. Give the chief the option to respond. But I think we, as you understand, have been restricted by the instruction of the administration and seeing no council members in queue to respond, we will move on to our next speaker, who is Ms. Lien Chong. Ms. Chong, if you're with us, we'll give you a moment to hit star six to unmute or otherwise speak up and we'll hear you. Hello, can you hear me? Yes, Ms. Chong. Go ahead. We hear you and see you online. Yes, ma'am. Thank you. Awesome. So I am an artist and I'm an organizer for Arts Accountability Houston. And we have many engaged artists who are advocating for public funding for the arts here in Houston. Now, we are aware of a proposal that's been sent to the mayor by the Cultural District for Arca funding to be allocated to the arts in Houston. I'd like to sort of as a member of the public Advocate for these fundings to go to fund the arts here in Houston. I know it's not on the budget, but we are curious to know when these funds will be confirmed from the city to support the arts here in Houston. Any organizations are still suffering as a result of the pandemic and we would really like for the city to allocate ARPA funding towards the arts here in Houston. Thank you very much, Mrs. Chong. We're well aware of the ongoing challenges for our arts community and thank you very much for bringing this question to council. It is something that we are working on with local organizations and appreciate you calling our attention to it and we will stay vigilant with that item. Next, we'll hear from Mr. Yes, ma'am. Thank you. We will respond accordingly. Our next speaker is Mr. Jason Oliver. Mr. Oliver, if you're with us or hit star six to unmute, I'm here. Good morning. First, I want to speak up in support of Leanne and the arts proposal. Like, there was significant losses and hot taxes and using ARPA funds for revenue replacement would be a great idea to kind of stimulate the economy and economic activity in Houston. First, and so along those lines, it's come up before, but I'm interested in the process for approving ARPA fund suggestions. Can you share that process and any rubric that exists? Also, I would like to see the proposals that have been received by the mayor's office thus far. And then second, HTV feels like an under celebrated entity within the city, but it's vital for transparency. As Ms. Hunter mentioned, the expenditures accepting a two and a half million furniture and equipment line item seemed flat decreasing over the past six years, even with the pandemic going on. I'm wondering if HTV saw an increased workload during the pandemic and if there was an increase in overtime or other pay, because I'm not seeing it in the line items. Thank you. Thank you, Mr. Oliver. I'm going to pick up on your final point there about the good work of HTV. And I know council members have been encouraged to utilize that facility and that ability for us to really program according to some of the highlights of what we're doing around City Hall. So, again, thank you for your question, for being here with us virtually. And Ms. Hunter, again, I want to thank you for your presentation today, for your team being here with us in chambers. And with that, we will take a break and resume after lunch this afternoon at 01:00 with presentation of the budget workshop. Our next group to hear from will be our legal department. And with that, our break commences. Thank you, Chair. Thank you, Council. Share the investment priorities identified by the Eastwood Civic Association. We need relief on three lines to improve mobility in our community. I will speak to the Galveston sub and my neighbor Lindsay, who's up next, will speak about east and west belts later on the Galveston sub. Our top priority is an underpass on lockwood, which was in the presentation. This is the expected route of Metro BRT's University corridor line. But let me be clear. Our neighborhood believes an overpass in this area wouldn't be the right solution. We are instead in favor of a small underpass that would provide the community with one additional north south crossing, but still leave seven crossings aggregate that are blocked daily. As such, I urge the city of Houston to also seek funding for a rail improvement study on this line to explore alternative solutions that address the entirety of the sub, not just one crossing. And this needs to be done in conjunction with Metro to ensure solutions can be expedited to align with the timelines for BRT construction. Thank you, Chair. My colleague Glimpsey will share priorities for East End, West Belt or east and west belts in her remarks. Thank you. Thank you very much, Ms. La Perrier, and we'll proceed with the I believe hold on. Before you leave the podium, we have a question from Chair Gallegos. Thank you, Daniel, for being here today and representing Eastwood. Just for your information, a couple of weeks ago, I did meet with the new board chair, Sanjay, and did bring that to his attention. He came into my office that there are concerns in regards to the BRT going down lockwood, in regards to an overpass that may be constructed or an underpass. So they are aware of it and we are going to be monitoring it. Thank you. Thank you, council member. Proceed to our next speaker. Thanks again. Ms. Lindsay Williams with us virtually and online. Proceed, ms Williams. If you'd hit star six to unmute, we'll await your comment. Ms. Lindsay Williams, online. We see you online. If you can unmute star six, we can come back to you if there are technical challenges. With that nice intro from Danielle, I'm sorry we can't take it right to Ms. Williams, but we'll come back to you if we can. Mr. Tom Thompson, also online, virtually testing our system here. Mr. Thompson, are you there? Are you able to mute unmute, please. Unmute. We see you, Mr. Thompson, and we know we heard you at the public session this week at council. We're checking our system to see if there's any technical challenges right now, but proceeding with our list, a call for either Ms. Williams or Mr. Thompson online. And while we're addressing the challenges there, we will proceed. Present here in chambers is Punkaj Wadha. Punkage is here with us. Let's hear from you at the podium, sir. Thank you for being here. If you could state your name for the record and proceed with your question or comment. Yes, sir. Thank you. Good morning. Good morning, Council. Good morning. Thank you for holding this meeting. Thank you, BNSF, for being present, providing vital rail services to our city and the country. I just want to say I love trains. I enjoy counting train cars with my kids as they roll by when I'm stuck at one of the block crossings, unfortunately. My name is Punkage Wadhwa. I'm part of the Houston Quiet Zones Committee, and I'm one of the residents in the neighborhoods that are near the BNSF rail line that runs parallel to the 34th street tracks just north outside of 610 Loop on the northwest side from the neighborhoods from Oak Forest all the way to Independence Heights. As you can see on the map I provided you guys, there are over 500 households that have voiced their support for the 34th Street Street quadzone corridor. Considering each household typically has two to four residents, there are at least several thousand Houstonians impacted by the train horns on this stretch of tracks. It's time to silence the train horns in Houston's. People in countries around the world live in communities that are much more dense without the obnoxiously loud train horns. Houston can do the same. We don't live in the 18 hundreds with coal fired trains belching out black soot black soot and polluting the environment, do we? Then why should we live with an outdated safety measure as a train horn? The train horn is the last resort for emergency situations, notifying anyone to get off the tracks, same as it is for when we drive our vehicles. We don't honk our horn every time we drive through an intersection. We don't honk our horn when we change lanes. So we have safety measures in place. And we have the technology to mandate, per the City of Houston infrastructure Design manual, to put these measures in place and have horns only as a last resort. Per the FRA. The City of Houston has the authority to mandate this, to put effective quiet zones in place, as you guys have discussed earlier today, and I know you guys are in process of doing that, but we need to do this now. It's long awaited. You guys are part of the quality of life committee. It's now time to make this better for all citizens. Quality of. Life, especially the thousands of Houstonians that have just advocated for this. If I may have one more minute. Well, you can conclude your remarks. Yeah, I have one more minute. I'll give you a few more seconds. I'm speaking on behalf of thousands of members of we have a long way to go today, Mr. Padwa. Thank you. Okay. Regarding funding and costs of the quiet zones, I don't think the city should be burdened with this, nor the taxpayers. Let's look at BNSF's financial statement. In 2021, they had 22 billions in revenue, 13 billions in expenses, with a net income of 7 billion. Now, if you look at the number, 350,000 was mentioned earlier as a cost per. If you'd like to intersection, we can take your comment online and we'll be happy to post it and circulate it to the committees. But thank you again for being here. I appreciate asking your question. I appreciate you allowing me to speak. If you could wrap up, you're looking at 0.3% of BNF's profits to implement a $2 million quiet zone along the 34th street corridor. Thank you very much. Appreciate that. Proceeding now to our next speaker. We're going to try again for online. Our speaker is Ms. Orlando Pulito. Ms. Pulito, if you're here, please join. There you are. Okay, thank you. Ms. Pulito, we can hear you. Hello? Go ahead, ma'am. We can hear you. Okay, thank you for allowing me a few minutes to speak. So I submitted in writing my concerns to back up what I'm speaking of today. So with the railroad I've been in this community for a very long time, and I'm just very upset. The fact that the railroad is sitting there talking about they have daily conversations, monthly meetings, but yet there's no solution. In addition to this blocking of vehicles having to reroute include massive 18 wheelers trying to get to these back industries, these are neighborhoods. These are small streets. And these massive trucks navigating through the community are not only tearing up our streets, but more importantly, we have a trail, walking trail. We have a park, but our wires sit low when they come through here, and I've already reported this numerous times, they cause damage to my house in more ways than one. They have popped my Internet wires, causing my whole house to be damaged. They forced their way in anyhow possible any way possible. And I've submitted pictures of that. We have children riding their bikes. We have people. We have older seniors walking. These trucks are trying to get to this industry. They're trying to exit this industry. Our community streets are not for that. And the young man before me was talking about the revenue. Yeah, there has to be alternative ways in these meetings that they have to put this revenue in effect. But more importantly is, yeah, we need solutions and we need them quickly. Thank you very much, Ms. Pulito. We do have the handout that you brought or delivered to us with the photographs that you mentioned. So thank you for that, and we will post those and circulate. So thank you again for your comments and being here. Seeing no questions from the council, we're going to proceed to the next speaker, which is Ms. Mara Gomez. Ms. Gomez is here with us in City Hall chambers, so thank you for being here. If you join us at the podium, we'd love to hear your comment or question today for the council. If you could identify yourself. Yes, good morning. My name is Mana Gomez, and I am with Link Houston, a nonprofit that advocates for a robust and equitable transportation network so that all people can reach opportunity. Today, I am addressing this joint committee about the increasing burden train blockages continue to pose for transit riders, bicyclists, and pedestrians in the East End and Fifth Ward communities. Link Houston shares many of the concerns residents are sharing with you today. I live in the East End, so I experience firsthand the impact these train blockages have on our communities. We are forced to reroute to access jobs, education, health care and wellness, recreational opportunities, and other essential destinations. For example, while riding Metro's 40 local bus route, one day, the driver had to reroute along the I 45 frontage road and missed ten stops on both sides of the train blockage. Several Metro bus routes are often forced to redirect when trains block a crossing, causing people to be late to their destinations. Some pedestrians, school age children included, go under or over in between the cars of trains of stopped trains blocking their route and risk their lives by doing so. Pedestrians will try to find the quickest way to their destination, especially if they're being late affects their quality of life. Additionally, they can force bicyclists to reroute onto busier streets, which may not have the built in infrastructure to afford sufficient safety. So today, we ask the Federal Railroad Administration, Up, BNSF and the KCS rail companies to work with our local elected officials and communities to find the best community driven solutions to these train blockages with our most vulnerable road users in mind, and without further dividing the communities the railway infrastructure goes through. And we ask our elected officials to help hold these companies accountable and do right by the communities they operate in. Your efforts to remedy these issues will remove adverse barriers and bring about equity in historically underserved areas. Thank you. Thank you very much, Ms. Gomez, for your comments. Seeing no questions in the queue, we'll proceed. I see that Ms. Williams has rejoined us or hopefully is able to unmute Ms. Williams. Can you do that? There you are. Yes. Can you hear me? Yes, go ahead. Loud and clear. Perfect. My name is Lindsay Williams. I'm the Eastwood Civic Association train committee chair, continuing to share our investment priorities. Danielle started with on the west belt. We agreed with the prioritization of York Street, presented by staff and included in the ten year old rail district study. However, there is a critical missing piece in Phase one needed to address the Nhhips plan. In anticipation of the closure at Polk and St. Emmanuel, we would urge the inclusion of an underpass at Leland as an equal priority. To allow Eastern residents a straight access to downtown on the East Belt, the community desperately needs at least one east west crossing, either at Polk lawndale or telephone. Each crossing has its merits. Polk serves as a route for Metro buses, lawndale would provide better access to Kip School and post office, and the telephone may undergo a complete transformation if the raised grant and Terra's 23 partnerships come through. There are test choices, but we'd be happy to work with the city to engage with the community on which crossing they would like to see prioritize. Moving on from infrastructure to Quiet Zones since at least 2011, the neighborhood has been seeking quiet zones across the West Belt, East Belt and the Galveston Line.
